high.label: High
high.description: Direct measurement, authoritative government report, real-time API, or peer-reviewed primary data

medium.label: Medium
medium.description: Model-based estimate, survey older than 5 years, compiled secondary source, or community-maintained data

low.label: Low
low.description: Derived or proxied from comparable sources, estimated value, very old data (>10 years), or single-sensor coverage

crossCitySources.name: Altmo Core API (Rails)
crossCitySources.description: Internal Rails 7 + PostgreSQL/PostGIS backend. Ingests GPS activity traces via Strava OAuth, validates against company geo-fences, aggregates leaderboards. 2.1M+ activities across 8 cities. ETL endpoints: /api/v1/activity_routes (routes with path arrays), /api/v1/leaderboards (company rankings), /api/v1/city_stats (city aggregations), /api/v1/companies + /api/v1/facilities (organisations). Additional endpoints available: /api/v1/routes/bulk, /api/v1/transit_activities, /api/v1/geo_markers, /api/v1/history.
crossCitySources.notes: Auth via access_token query param (RAILS_API_ACCESS_TOKEN). CO2 = distance(km) x 0.25 kg, Petrol = distance(km) x 0.108 L, Money = petrol x 101 INR

crossCitySources.name: Strava API (via Altmo Core)
crossCitySources.description: Primary activity data source. Users connect via OAuth, activities pulled automatically + via webhooks. Provides GPS polylines, distance, speed, elapsed time, activity type (Ride/Walk/Run). Direction detection (to/from work) via PostGIS proximity to company geo-markers (1km radius).

crossCitySources.name: Allirani & Verma (2025) — TQOLI Framework
crossCitySources.description: "A novel transportation Quality of Life Index framework for evaluating sustainable transport interventions", IISc Bangalore. Provides dimension weights (Fuzzy-AHP), scenario strategies (ST1/ST2), and Bengaluru baseline intervention coefficients. City-specific coefficients for other cities are derived from local transport studies (DIMTS, CMRL, HMRL, PMPML, KMRL, AICTSL, RITES DPRs) and Census 2011 mode share data.

crossCitySources.name: OpenAQ v3 API
crossCitySources.description: Real-time PM2.5 and NO2 measurements from CPCB-operated government monitoring stations. Sensor-based endpoint: /sensors/{id}/measurements. PM2.5 sensors (parameters_id=2) active for 9 cities. NO2 sensors (parameters_id=4) to be discovered — cities with empty sensor config fall back to CPCB annual averages.

crossCitySources.name: CPCB National Ambient Air Quality Status
crossCitySources.description: Central Pollution Control Board annual PM2.5 and NO2 averages from continuous ambient air quality monitoring stations. Baseline values for all cities.

crossCitySources.name: TomTom Traffic Flow API
crossCitySources.description: Real-time traffic flow data from 5-8 major arterial junctions per city. Congestion calculated as: ((freeFlowSpeed / currentSpeed) - 1) x 100. Sampled at representative road segments.

crossCitySources.name: TomTom Traffic Index (Annual)
crossCitySources.description: Annual city-level congestion rankings. Baseline congestion percentages for static QoL scoring.

crossCitySources.name: NCRB — Accidental Deaths & Suicides in India
crossCitySources.description: National Crime Records Bureau annual report. City-wise traffic accident fatalities normalised to per-lakh population rates.

crossCitySources.name: MoRTH — Road Accidents in India
crossCitySources.description: Ministry of Road Transport & Highways annual accident statistics. Used for cities not covered by NCRB city-level data (e.g. Indore).

crossCitySources.name: Census of India 2011
crossCitySources.description: Decennial census mode share data (walk, cycle, public transport, private vehicle) for urban areas. Used as baseline for cities without recent CMP/CTTS surveys.

crossCitySources.name: TransitRouter (Vonter)
crossCitySources.description: Open-source bus stops and services data for 9 Indian regions. Provides GTFS-like stop coordinates and route mappings. Data fetched from GitHub raw files. Also used to estimate PT accessibility (% city area within 500m of stops).

crossCitySources.name: UrbanEmissions.info — APnA City Program
crossCitySources.description: City-level PM2.5 source apportionment using WRF-CAMx dispersion modelling (Guttikunda et al. 2019). Provides sector-wise emission shares: transport, industry, dust, waste burning, residential, DG sets.

crossCitySources.name: CEA CO2 Baseline Database v21.0
crossCitySources.description: Central Electricity Authority grid emission factors by region and state. National weighted average: 0.710 tCO2/MWh (FY 2024-25). Used for grid renewables baseline in scenario modelling.

crossCitySources.name: WHO Air Quality Guidelines 2021
crossCitySources.description: WHO global air quality guideline values. Annual PM2.5 guideline: 5 ug/m3, 24-hour: 15 ug/m3. Annual NO2 guideline: 10 ug/m3. Used as ETQOLI benchmark reference.

crossCitySources.name: India NAAQS (National Ambient Air Quality Standards)
crossCitySources.description: Indian national air quality standards. Annual PM2.5 standard: 40 ug/m3, 24-hour: 60 ug/m3. Annual NO2 standard: 40 ug/m3. Reference for AQI category breakpoints.

sources.name: CEPT CTTS 2019 — Ahmedabad Mode Share
sources.description: CEPT University Comprehensive Traffic & Transportation Study for Ahmedabad. Mode share: Walking 24%, Cycling 8%, PT ~11%. Footpath coverage: 25% of roads (AMC Smart City report).

sources.name: Ahmedabad Metro (Overpass/OSM)
sources.description: Metro stations and lines fetched via Overpass API from OpenStreetMap. Phase 1: 40 km (Blue Line East-West + Red Line North-South). 32 stations.

sources.name: AMTS + Janmarg BRT — Bus Fleet
sources.description: Ahmedabad Municipal Transport Service ~1,200 buses + Janmarg BRT ~200 vehicles for ~55 lakh AMC population = 23 per lakh. India's first BRT system (2009).

sources.name: Sabarmati Riverfront + BRTS Cycle Tracks
sources.description: Cycle tracks along Sabarmati Riverfront promenade and Janmarg BRT corridors: ~20 km of dedicated cycle infrastructure.

sources.name: OpenAQ — Ahmedabad Sensors
sources.description: CPCB/GPCB PM2.5 monitoring stations near Ahmedabad. Sensor IDs pending discovery via /v3/locations endpoint. Baseline 2023 annual: PM2.5 55 ug/m3, NO2 35 ug/m3.

sources.name: UrbanEmissions — Ahmedabad APnA
sources.description: PM2.5 source apportionment: Industry dominant at 63% (textile mills, chemical plants, Naroda industrial estate), Transport only 11% (lowest among Altmo cities), Power generation 10%. Modeled annual: 52 ug/m3.

sources.name: Gujarat Grid Energy Mix
sources.description: Gujarat grid: ~30-38% renewable (15-20% solar — Charanka Solar Park + rooftop, 8-12% wind — Kutch corridor, 2-3% hydro), ~40-50% coal, ~15-20% gas (Hazira RLNG). Leading solar state with aggressive RPO targets.

sources.name: NCRB 2022 — Ahmedabad
sources.description: Traffic fatalities: 418 deaths in 2022, ~55 lakh AMC population = 7.6 per lakh. Source: NCRB / AMC Traffic Cell.

sources.name: CEPT / Janmarg — Ahmedabad Transport Coefficients
sources.description: Scenario intervention coefficients calibrated from CEPT CTTS mode share data, Janmarg BRT ridership elasticities, Gujarat Metro DPR demand forecasts, and Census 2011 baselines. Metro congestion: -0.025 pp/km, mode share: +0.025 pp/km. Bus congestion: -4 pp/2x, mode share: +5 pp/2x. High cycle lane responsiveness (+0.025 pp/km) reflecting moderate existing cycling culture (8% mode share).

sources.name: AMC Road Network
sources.description: AMC jurisdiction: 464 km2 with ~2,550 km of roads = 5.5 km/km2 road density. Source: AMC Smart City CDP.

sources.name: DULT Comprehensive Mobility Plan 2020
sources.description: Directorate of Urban Land Transport — Bengaluru CMP with mode share, travel demand, and infrastructure data. Walking 22%, Cycling 5%, PT 48%. Also: footpath coverage audit (37% of roads with paved footpaths).

sources.name: OpenCity — Bengaluru CMP Dataset
sources.description: Open data portal hosting the Bengaluru Comprehensive Mobility Plan tables and mode share breakdowns.

sources.name: Namma Metro GeoJSON (geohacker)
sources.description: Metro station locations and line geometry for BMRCL Phase 1 + 2A (73.8 km operational as of 2024). GeoJSON with station Name and line color.

sources.name: BMRCL Hourly Ridership (Vonter)
sources.description: Station-wise hourly ridership data for Bengaluru metro. CSV format: Date;Hour;Station;Ridership. Only city with metro ridership data.

sources.name: BMTC (Bangalore Metropolitan Transport Corporation)
sources.description: Bus fleet size: ~6,500 buses for ~1.23 crore population (53 per lakh). Routes and services via TransitRouter.

sources.name: OpenAQ — Bengaluru Sensors
sources.description: 7 CPCB PM2.5 monitoring stations. Sensor IDs: 12235361, 12235370, 12235267, 12235240, 12235285, 12235258, 12235249. Baseline 2023 annual: PM2.5 34 ug/m3, NO2 30 ug/m3. NO2 sensor IDs pending discovery.

sources.name: TenderSURE + Cycle Tracks — Bengaluru
sources.description: Dedicated cycle lane/track length in Bengaluru: ~15 km from TenderSURE road redesign pilot and scattered cycle tracks.

sources.name: UrbanEmissions — Bengaluru APnA
sources.description: PM2.5 source apportionment: Transport 44% (exhaust + road dust), Industry 8-10%, Dust 20-23%. Based on Guttikunda & Jawahar (2019) WRF-CAMx modelling. No coal power plants in airshed.

sources.name: Karnataka Grid Energy Mix
sources.description: Karnataka state grid: ~55-62% renewable (22-25% hydro, 15-18% solar, 12-14% wind), ~35-40% coal/thermal. India's #1 ranked state in clean electricity transition (Ember SET 2024).

sources.name: BBMP Road Network
sources.description: BBMP jurisdiction: 764 km2 with ~7,800 km of roads = 10.2 km/km2 road density. Source: Smart Cities data.

sources.name: NCRB 2022 — Bengaluru
sources.description: 960 traffic fatalities in 2022, ~1.23 crore population = 7.8 per lakh. Source: NCRB Accidental Deaths & Suicides in India.

sources.name: Vajjarapu et al. (2023) — Travel Demand Model
sources.description: "Evaluating Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation Strategies for Transport" — Bengaluru travel demand modelling for scenario validation.

sources.name: CMDA — Comprehensive Traffic & Transportation Study
sources.description: Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority CTTS. Mode share: Walking 24%, Cycling 4%, Bus 26%, Two-wheeler 25%. Footpath coverage: 45% of roads. Data from 2008/2018 surveys.

sources.name: JICA — Chennai Data Collection Survey
sources.description: Japan International Cooperation Agency data collection survey on urban transport planning in Chennai metropolitan area.

sources.name: Southern Railway Suburban / MRTS — Chennai
sources.description: Chennai suburban railway (Southern Railway): ~510 km broad gauge network + MRTS 19.3 km elevated. 148 stations. ~1.2M daily riders. Key corridors: Beach-Tambaram, Beach-Velachery (MRTS), Arakkonam line, Tiruvallur line. Combined with metro: 584 km rail transit.

sources.name: Chennai Suburban Rail (Overpass/OSM)
sources.description: Suburban rail stations and lines fetched via Overpass API from OpenStreetMap. Networks: Southern Railway (Chennai Suburban Railway) + Chennai MRTS. Corridors: Beach-Tambaram, Beach-Velachery (MRTS), Arakkonam, Tiruvallur, Gummidipoondi.
Metro stations and lines fetched via Overpass API from OpenStreetMap. Phase 1 + extension: 54.6 km (2024). Lines: Blue Line, Green Line.

sources.name: MTC (Metropolitan Transport Corporation)
sources.description: Bus fleet: ~3,500 buses for ~87 lakh population = 40 per lakh. Routes and services via TransitRouter.

sources.name: OpenAQ — Chennai Sensors
sources.description: 7 CPCB PM2.5 monitoring stations. Sensor IDs: 12235653, 12235531, 12235796, 12236299, 12236308, 12236274, 12236290. Baseline 2023 annual: PM2.5 31 ug/m3, NO2 25 ug/m3. NO2 sensor IDs pending discovery.

sources.name: Smart City Cycle Corridors — Chennai
sources.description: Chennai Smart City Limited cycle corridor projects: ~10 km of dedicated cycle lanes on Smart City corridors.

sources.name: UrbanEmissions — Chennai APnA
sources.description: PM2.5 source apportionment: Transport 20-25% (depressed by massive industrial base), Industry (incl. power) 70%, Power generation alone 15-25% (North Chennai Thermal Power Station). Modeled annual: 57.5 ug/m3.

sources.name: Tamil Nadu Grid Energy Mix
sources.description: Tamil Nadu grid: ~38-45% renewable (18-22% wind, 10-14% solar, 4-6% hydro), ~45-50% coal/thermal, ~5-7% nuclear. 50% RE installed capacity but lower generation share.

sources.name: NCRB 2022 — Chennai
sources.description: Traffic fatalities: 10.5 per lakh population (2022). Source: NCRB.

sources.name: CMRL / CTTS — Chennai Transport Coefficients
sources.description: Scenario intervention coefficients calibrated from CMRL (Chennai Metro Rail Limited) ridership data, CMDA CTTS mode share surveys, and MTC bus operations. Metro congestion effect: -0.02 pp/km, mode share: +0.04 pp/km. Bus effects are strongest among Altmo cities due to MTC dominance: congestion -5 pp/2x, mode share +8 pp/2x.

sources.name: Census 2011 — Delhi Mode Share
sources.description: Delhi mode share: Walking 16%, Cycling 6%, Public transport 42%. Census 2011 urban transport data.

sources.name: RITES/DIMTS Transport Demand Forecast
sources.description: Delhi Transport Department travel demand forecasts, mode share studies, and DIMTS pedestrian audit (footpath coverage: 25% of roads).

sources.name: Delhi Open Transit Data (OTD)
sources.description: GTFS feeds for Delhi public transport including DTC buses and metro.

sources.name: RRTS / Namo Bharat — Delhi NCR
sources.description: Regional Rapid Transit System (NCRTC): Delhi-Meerut corridor 55 km operational (2025). Namo Bharat branded. Adds commuter rail capacity to Delhi NCT. Combined with DMRC: 448 km rail transit.
Delhi Metro: 393 km operational — largest in India (2024). Station data from dhirajt/delhi-metro-stations GitHub.

sources.name: Delhi Metro Stations GeoJSON
sources.description: GeoJSON of all Delhi metro stations. Used for map rendering and accessibility analysis.

sources.name: Delhi Metro Lines GeoJSON
sources.description: Delhi NCR metro line geometries for map rendering.

sources.name: DTC + Cluster Bus Fleet
sources.description: DTC ~3,700 + cluster ~3,500 buses for ~2.1 crore population = 32 per lakh. DTC fleet includes 3,109 CNG + 1,250 electric buses.

sources.name: OpenAQ — Delhi Sensors
sources.description: 10 CPCB PM2.5 monitoring stations — most sensors of any Altmo city. Sensor IDs: 12234787, 12234796, 12235610, etc. Baseline 2023 annual: PM2.5 99 ug/m3 (worst in India), NO2 60 ug/m3. NO2 sensor IDs pending discovery.

sources.name: DDA Painted Cycle Tracks — Delhi
sources.description: Delhi Development Authority painted cycle tracks: ~25 km across arterial roads. Includes cycle lanes on BRT corridor remnants.

sources.name: UrbanEmissions — Delhi Source Apportionment
sources.description: Multiple studies synthesised: Transport 28-40% (exhaust + road dust), Power generation 3-8% (post-Badarpur closure 2018), Biomass 13-30%, Secondary PM 30-34%. Best central estimate: Transport 33%, Power 5%.

sources.name: TERI — Delhi NCR Source Apportionment (2018)
sources.description: TERI-ARAI hybrid emission inventory + CTM study. Transport share 13-39% depending on domain (NCR vs city). Power/energy ~3.4% for Delhi city.

sources.name: RMI — Transforming Delhi's Power Grid
sources.description: Delhi grid: ~25-33% renewable (8-14% solar, 12-17% hydro), ~55-60% coal (from imports), ~8-11% gas. Delhi imports ~90% of power. Projects coal share declining to ~37% by 2030.

sources.name: NCRB 2022 — Delhi
sources.description: Traffic fatalities: 11.3 per lakh population (2022) — highest absolute numbers. Source: NCRB.

sources.name: DIMTS / RITES — Delhi Transport Coefficients
sources.description: Scenario intervention coefficients calibrated from DIMTS (Delhi Integrated Multi-Modal Transit System) ridership elasticities, RITES travel demand forecasts, and Census 2011 mode share baselines. Metro congestion effect: -0.04 pp/km, mode share: +0.04 pp/km. Bus congestion: -3.5 pp/2x, mode share: +3.5 pp/2x.

sources.name: Census/CMP — Hyderabad Mode Share
sources.description: Hyderabad mode share: Walking 20%, Cycling 5%, Public transport 31% (highest PT share among Altmo cities). HMDA CMP footpath coverage: 30% of roads. Census 2011 + CMP data.

sources.name: MMTS (Multi-Modal Transport System) — Hyderabad
sources.description: Hyderabad MMTS suburban rail: 90 km network (South Central Railway), 36 stations. Key corridors: Lingampalli-Falaknuma, Hyderabad-Secunderabad. Combined with HMR: 159 km rail transit.

sources.name: Hyderabad MMTS (Overpass/OSM)
sources.description: MMTS suburban rail stations and lines fetched via Overpass API from OpenStreetMap. Network: Hyderabad MMTS. Corridors: Lingampalli-Falaknuma, Secunderabad-Medchal, Lingampalli-Ghatkesar.
Hyderabad Metro Rail Limited open data portal. HMR Line 1 + Line 2 + Line 3: 69.2 km operational (2024).

sources.name: Hyderabad Metro GeoJSON (kavyajeetbora)
sources.description: Station buildings and route GeoJSON for Hyderabad metro mapping and accessibility analysis.

sources.name: Telangana GTFS — HMRL
sources.description: GTFS feed for Hyderabad metro from Telangana Open Data Portal.

sources.name: TSRTC City Bus Services
sources.description: Telangana State Road Transport Corporation city services: ~3,000 buses for ~1 crore population = 30 per lakh.

sources.name: OpenAQ — Hyderabad Sensors
sources.description: 7 PM2.5 monitoring stations. Sensor IDs: 12235583, 12235400, 12242121, 12242129, 12237098, 12237125, 12237116. Baseline 2023 annual: PM2.5 37 ug/m3, NO2 28 ug/m3. NO2 sensor IDs pending discovery.

sources.name: Cycle Infrastructure — Hyderabad
sources.description: Limited dedicated cycle infrastructure in Hyderabad: ~8 km of cycle tracks, mostly along GHMC pilot corridors.

sources.name: UrbanEmissions — Hyderabad APnA
sources.description: PM2.5 source apportionment: Transport 35-45% (CPCB receptor study: vehicle 31% + dust 26%), Power generation 3-5% (regional, no major plants in airshed), Industry 20-29%. Emission inventory: 34,750 tonnes/year.

sources.name: Guttikunda & Kopakka (2013) — Hyderabad EMAS
sources.description: CPCB-funded receptor model study for Hyderabad PM2.5 source apportionment. Found: vehicular 31%, dust 26%, combustion 9%, industrial 7%, refuse 6%.

sources.name: Telangana Grid Energy Mix
sources.description: Telangana grid: ~18-24% renewable (8-10% solar, 8-12% hydro, 1-2% wind), ~75-82% coal/thermal. TSGENCO capacity >90% thermal. Target: 50% green power by 2030.

sources.name: NCRB 2022 — Hyderabad
sources.description: Traffic fatalities: 8.4 per lakh population (2022). Source: NCRB.

sources.name: HMRL — Hyderabad Transport Coefficients
sources.description: Scenario intervention coefficients calibrated from HMRL ridership elasticities, TSRTC bus operations data, and Census 2011 mode share baselines. Metro congestion: -0.035 pp/km, mode share: +0.04 pp/km. Bus congestion: -3.5 pp/2x, mode share: +5 pp/2x. Cycle effects moderated by climate and terrain.

sources.name: CMP/ICLEI — Indore Mode Share
sources.description: Indore mode share from CMP and ICLEI Sustainable Mobility Plan: Walking 22%, Cycling 5%, PT ~18%. Smart City CDP estimate: footpath coverage 20% of roads.

sources.name: Indore Metro Rail (under construction)
sources.description: Metro under construction as of 2024. Priority corridor opened May 2025. Current operational km: 0 (at time of data entry).
sources.notes: Slider starts at 0 km in scenario tool; represents building from scratch

sources.name: AICTSL Bus Fleet
sources.description: Atal Indore City Transport Service Limited: ~387 buses for ~35 lakh metro population = 11 per lakh. i-Bus branded fleet.

sources.name: BRTS Corridor Cycle Tracks — Indore
sources.description: Cycle tracks along Indore BRTS (iBus) corridor: ~12 km of dedicated cycle infrastructure.

sources.name: OpenAQ — Indore Sensors
sources.description: 6 PM2.5 monitoring stations. Sensor IDs: 12234921, 12237818, 12238477, 12238486, 12815122, 12238495. Baseline: PM2.5 56 ug/m3 (UrbanEmissions + IQAir), NO2 35 ug/m3 (CPCB estimate). NO2 sensor IDs pending discovery.
sources.notes: Indore uses UrbanEmissions model + IQAir estimates for baseline (CPCB station limited coverage)

sources.name: UrbanEmissions — Indore APnA
sources.description: PM2.5 source apportionment: Transport 45-55% (highest transport share), Power generation 1-3% (no coal plants in airshed), Dust 24%, Waste burning 8.4%. Emission inventory: 11,850 tonnes/year. Modeled annual: 66.3 ug/m3.

sources.name: Madhya Pradesh Grid Energy Mix
sources.description: MP grid: ~25-32% renewable (10-14% solar, 8-10% hydro, 5-7% wind), ~65-72% coal/thermal, ~1-2% nuclear. Capacity allocation (2023): thermal 62.5%, RE 23.6%, hydro 12.4%.

sources.name: MoRTH 2022 — Indore
sources.description: Traffic fatalities: 639 deaths, ~35 lakh metro population = 18.3 per lakh (2022). Source: MoRTH (NCRB city-level data not available).

sources.name: Congestion Estimate (comparable cities)
sources.description: TomTom Traffic Index not available for Indore. Congestion estimated at 33% based on comparable mid-size Indian cities.
sources.notes: Estimated — TomTom does not cover Indore directly

sources.name: AICTSL / RITES — Indore Transport Coefficients
sources.description: Scenario intervention coefficients calibrated from AICTSL iBus BRT operations, RITES metro DPR demand forecasts, ICLEI CMP mode share data, and Census 2011 baselines. Metro effects conservative (no operational metro): -0.02 pp/km congestion, +0.02 pp/km mode share. Bus congestion: -5 pp/2x, mode share: +5 pp/2x. High cycle lane responsiveness (+0.03 pp/km) reflecting flat terrain and existing cycling culture.

sources.name: Census 2011 — Kochi Mode Share
sources.description: Kochi mode share: Walking 22%, Cycling 5%, NMT total 42% (walk+cycle highest among Altmo cities). Census 2011 urban data. Kerala urban walkability study: footpath coverage 35% of roads.

sources.name: KMRL Open Data (GTFS)
sources.description: Kochi Metro Rail Limited GTFS feed — first Indian metro to publish GTFS (March 2018). Single line: 25.6 km. Includes stops.txt, shapes.txt, routes.txt.

sources.name: KSRTC City Bus Services
sources.description: Kerala State Road Transport Corporation city services + private operators: ~400 buses for ~21 lakh population = 20 per lakh.

sources.name: Cycle Infrastructure — Kochi
sources.description: Minimal dedicated cycle infrastructure in Kochi: ~5 km. Compact urban form supports cycling but no protected lanes.

sources.name: OpenAQ — Kochi Sensors
sources.description: 1 CPCB PM2.5 monitoring station — fewest sensors of any Altmo city. Sensor ID: 12235842. Baseline 2023 annual: PM2.5 27 ug/m3 (cleanest city), NO2 18 ug/m3 (lowest). NO2 sensor IDs pending discovery.

sources.name: UrbanEmissions — Kochi APnA
sources.description: PM2.5 source apportionment: Transport 35-40% (exhaust + road dust), Power generation 2-4% (Kerala has minimal coal power), Industry 25-28% (petrochemicals, fertilizers). Emission inventory: 9,150 tonnes/year. Modeled annual: 29.1 ug/m3.

sources.name: Kerala Grid Energy Mix
sources.description: Kerala grid: In-state generation ~80-90% renewable (60-70% hydro, 15-20% solar), BUT imports 70-80% of total consumption. Effective consumption-weighted mix: ~25-30% renewable, ~60-65% coal (from imports).
sources.notes: Kerala imports majority of power; effective coal share much higher than in-state generation suggests

sources.name: NCRB 2022 — Kochi (Kerala state rate)
sources.description: Traffic fatalities: 9.2 per lakh population (2022). Uses Kerala state rate as city-specific data not available. Source: NCRB.

sources.name: KMRL — Kochi Transport Coefficients
sources.description: Scenario intervention coefficients calibrated from KMRL GTFS ridership data, KSRTC city bus operations, and Census 2011 mode share baselines. Metro effects moderate (single-line system): -0.025 pp/km congestion, +0.025 pp/km mode share. Bus congestion: -3.5 pp/2x, mode share: +3.5 pp/2x. Higher cycle congestion relief (-0.012 pp/km) due to compact urban form.

sources.name: Census/CMP — Mumbai Mode Share
sources.description: Mumbai mode share: Walking 27%, Cycling 3%, Suburban rail 15%, Bus 15%, Metro 1%. Sustainable mode share: 58% (highest among Altmo cities). MCGM Pedestrian First: 35% footpath coverage on arterials.

sources.name: Mumbai Suburban Railway (Western + Central + Harbour)
sources.description: Mumbai suburban railway backbone: 465 km total (Western Railway 124 km, Central Railway 170 km, Harbour Line 54 km, Trans-Harbour 22 km, others). 125 stations. 7.5M daily riders — world's densest commuter rail. Combined with metro: 545 km rail transit.

sources.name: Mumbai Suburban Rail (Overpass/OSM)
sources.description: Suburban rail stations and lines fetched via Overpass API from OpenStreetMap. Network: Mumbai Suburban Railway. Lines: Western, Central, Harbour, Trans-Harbour, Vasai-Diva, Nerul-Uran.

sources.name: Mumbai Metro (Overpass/OSM)
sources.description: Metro stations and lines fetched via Overpass API from OpenStreetMap. 80 km operational (2025): Blue Line 1 (11.4 km), Yellow Line 2A (18.6 km), Red Line 7 (16.5 km), Aqua Line 3 (33.5 km). 69 stations.

sources.name: BEST Bus Fleet
sources.description: Brihanmumbai Electric Supply and Transport: ~2,900 buses for ~1.3 crore population = 22 per lakh. Includes 386 electric buses (2024). BEST ridership: ~30 lakh/day.

sources.name: OpenAQ — Mumbai Sensors
sources.description: CPCB PM2.5 monitoring stations near Mumbai. Sensor IDs pending discovery via /v3/locations endpoint. Baseline 2023 annual: PM2.5 38 ug/m3, NO2 32 ug/m3.

sources.name: Cycle Infrastructure — Mumbai
sources.description: Virtually no dedicated cycle infrastructure in Mumbai: ~5 km (BKC track defunct). Geography (narrow peninsula) and traffic volumes limit cycling.

sources.name: UrbanEmissions — Mumbai APnA / NEERI-MCGM Study
sources.description: PM2.5 source apportionment: Transport 25-35% (NEERI-MCGM receptor study), Power generation 6-10% (Dahanu TPS + industrial), Industry 25-30% (port, refineries), Sea salt/secondary 15-20%. Emission inventory: 48,500 tonnes/year.

sources.name: Maharashtra Grid Energy Mix
sources.description: Maharashtra grid: ~18-22% renewable, ~72-78% coal/thermal. Same state as Pune. Baseline: 20% renewable.

sources.name: Mumbai Road Safety Report 2022 (Bloomberg BIGRS)
sources.description: Bloomberg Initiative for Global Road Safety partner city. 365 fatalities in 2022, ~1.3 crore population = 2.8 per lakh — lowest fatality rate among all Altmo cities. Pedestrians account for 44% of fatalities.

sources.name: BMC Road Network
sources.description: BMC jurisdiction: 603 km2 with ~5,000 km of roads = 8.3 km/km2 road density. Source: MCGM infrastructure report.

sources.name: NEERI / BEST — Mumbai Transport Coefficients
sources.description: Scenario intervention coefficients calibrated from BEST ridership data, suburban railway mode share elasticities, MMRDA CTTS forecasts, and Census 2011 baselines. Metro congestion: -0.025 pp/km, mode share: +0.03 pp/km. Bus congestion: -3.5 pp/2x, mode share: +4 pp/2x. Cycle effects muted due to geography and traffic density.

sources.name: OpenCity — Pune CMP Dataset
sources.description: Pune Comprehensive Mobility Plan. Mode share (2018): Walking 25%, Cycling 15% (highest cycling share — flat terrain, cycle culture), PT 12%, Private 48%. PMC footpath survey: 40% of roads with paved footpaths.

sources.name: PMPML Vision 2027 (ITDP)
sources.description: ITDP Pune Municipal Parivahan Mahamandal Ltd bus reform vision document.

sources.name: Pune Suburban Railway (Pune-Lonavala)
sources.description: Pune suburban rail (Central Railway): ~64 km Pune-Lonavala corridor, 17 stations. Under expansion as part of Pune Metro Region Development Authority plans. Combined with metro: 97 km rail transit.

sources.name: Pune Suburban Rail (Overpass/OSM)
sources.description: Suburban rail stations and lines fetched via Overpass API from OpenStreetMap. Network: Pune Suburban Railway. Corridor: Pune-Lonavala.
Metro stations and lines fetched via Overpass API from OpenStreetMap. Phase 1 (partial, 2024): 33.3 km. Lines: Purple Line, Aqua Line.

sources.name: PMPML Bus Fleet
sources.description: Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited: ~2,000 buses for ~78 lakh population = 25 per lakh.

sources.name: OpenAQ — Pune Sensors
sources.description: 7 PM2.5 monitoring stations. Sensor IDs: 12235540, 12236443, 12236457, 12236463, 12236449, 12304615, 12237987. Baseline 2023 annual: PM2.5 36 ug/m3, NO2 32 ug/m3. NO2 sensor IDs pending discovery.

sources.name: PMC Cycle Tracks + BRT — Pune
sources.description: Pune Municipal Corporation cycle tracks and BRT corridor cycle lanes: ~50 km — highest cycle infrastructure among Altmo cities, reflecting Pune's strong cycling culture.

sources.name: ARAI — Pune District Emission Inventory (2022)
sources.description: ARAI 2022 Pune emission inventory: Transport exhaust 20%, Road dust 19%, Industry 19%, Construction 12%, Agri waste 10%, Residential 6%, Waste burning 6%, DG sets 4%.

sources.name: SAFAR — Pune Emission Inventory (2021)
sources.description: System of Air Quality Forecasting and Research (IITM Pune) emission inventory for Pune district.

sources.name: UrbanEmissions — Pune APnA
sources.description: PM2.5 source apportionment: Transport 30-39% (exhaust 20% + road dust 19%), Power generation 3-6% (no coal plants in city), Industry 19%. 25% of ambient PM2.5 from outside urban airshed.

sources.name: Maharashtra Grid Energy Mix
sources.description: Maharashtra grid: ~18-22% renewable (6-8% wind, 4-6% solar, 5-7% hydro), ~72-78% coal/thermal, ~2-4% gas. MAHAGENCO FY2025: 89% thermal, 6.6% hydro, 4% gas, 0.6% solar.

sources.name: NCRB 2022 — Pune
sources.description: Traffic fatalities: 7.1 per lakh population (2022) — lowest among Altmo cities. Source: NCRB.

sources.name: TERI — Pune Action Prioritisation (2024)
sources.description: TERI report on prioritisation of NCAP actions for Pune and Nashik. Includes source apportionment validation.

sources.name: PMPML / Pune CMP — Transport Coefficients
sources.description: Scenario intervention coefficients calibrated from PMPML bus ridership data, ITDP Vision 2027 demand projections, Pune CMP mode share, and Census 2011 baselines. Metro effects moderate (new system): -0.025 pp/km congestion, +0.025 pp/km mode share. Bus congestion: -5 pp/2x, mode share: +6 pp/2x. Highest cycle lane responsiveness (+0.03 pp/km) alongside Indore — reflecting Pune's flat terrain and strong existing cycling culture (15% mode share).
